description: Practice boulangerie vocabulary through writing and reading exercises.

questions.explanation: French law requires boulangeries to make their bread fresh on-site.

questions.question: How do you say "pastry shop"?
questions.explanation: Technically, a boulangerie only sells breads and pastries made with dough, while a patisserie focuses on sweeter pastries and desserts. However, the lines can blur a bit. Most boulangeries will sell at least some sweet pastries, and in rural areas, the boulangerie may be the only place to get any pastries at all.

questions.question: How do you say "here is your change
questions.explanation: You may also find bakeries with automatic coin dispensers. They work by accepting cash that you insert. The machine then verifies the bill's authenticity and dispenses the equivalent amount in coins. It's like you have won the slots when the change comes out.

questions.question: How do you ask "anything else/is that all"?
questions.explanation: When the person feels that you have finished ordering, she might ask ce sera tout ? (is that all?) expecting a yes or no answer. If you say yes, she will give you the price. If you say no, she will expect you to ask for what more you want to order. Et voilà !

questions.question: How do you order a baguette?
options: A. Une baguette s'il vous plait ?
B. Puis-je avoir une baguette s'il vous plait ?
C. Est-ce que vous avez une baguette s'il vous plait ?
questions.explanation: There are about 30,000 boulangeries in France. A lot of places to practise asking for bread!
